item.title: Resident Alien (American television series)
item.description:
Resident Alien (American television series) ðŸ”—

This is a comprehensive description of the Wikipedia article for the American television series Resident Alien.

Overview ðŸ”—

This section provides a brief introduction to the television series Resident Alien. It establishes the show’s genre as a science fiction mystery comedy-drama and identifies Chris Sheridan as the creator. It also mentions that the show is based on the comic book series of the same name by Peter Hogan and Steve Parkhouse. The premiere date of the first season on Syfy is noted, along with the star, Alan Tudyk. The renewals for subsequent seasons, including the move to USA Network for the fourth season, are also mentioned.

Premise ðŸ”—

This section outlines the central plot of the series. An alien arrives on Earth with the mission to wipe out humanity. After crashing in Colorado, the alien assumes the identity of a doctor named Harry Vanderspeigle. As he lives among humans, he begins to question his mission. A young boy, Max Hawthorne, can see through his disguise. The alien grapples with his mission and ultimately defends humanity from other extraterrestrial threats.

Cast and characters ðŸ”—

This section details the main and recurring cast members and their respective characters.

Main ðŸ”—

  • Alan Tudyk plays the alien, who takes on the identity of Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle. He is sent to Earth to destroy humanity but develops compassion. Tudyk also portrays the real Dr. Harry Vanderspeigle.
  • Sara Tomko plays Asta Twelvetrees, the assistant to the town doctor and a member of the Ute tribe. She is the first person after Max to discover Harry’s true identity.
  • Corey Reynolds plays Sheriff Mike Thompson, the town’s sheriff, who is dealing with past trauma.
  • Alice Wetterlund plays D’arcy Bloom, the owner of the town pub and Asta’s best friend. She discovers Harry’s true identity after learning that the real Harry killed Sam Hodges.
  • Levi Fiehler plays Ben Hawthorne, the town’s mayor, who has a history of alien abductions.
  • Judah Prehn plays Max Hawthorne, Ben’s son, who can see Harry’s alien form.
  • Elizabeth Bowen plays Deputy Liv Baker, the town’s deputy, who is fascinated by extraterrestrials.

Recurring ðŸ”—

This section lists actors and the recurring characters they portray, including:

  • Meredith Garretson as Kate Hawthorne
  • Ben Cotton as Jimmy
  • Kaylayla Raine as Jay
  • Deborah Finkel as Abigail Hodges
  • Gary Farmer as Dan Twelvetrees
  • Mandell Maughan as Agent Lisa Casper
  • Alex Barima as Lieutenant David Logan
  • Jenna Lamia as Judy Cooper
  • Sarah Podemski as Kayla
  • Diana Bang as Ellen Cho
  • Elvy Yost as Isabelle Vanderspeigle
  • Gracelyn Awad Rinke as Sahar
  • Linda Hamilton as General Eleanor McCallister
  • Michael Cassidy as Dr. Ethan Stone
  • Nathan Fillion as the voice of 42
  • Alvin Sanders as Lewis Thompson
  • Trevor Carroll as John Baker
  • Terry O’Quinn as Peter Bach
  • Justin Rain as Elliot
  • Paul Piaskowski as Robert Hutchins
  • Enver Gjokaj as Joseph Rainier
  • Nicola Correia-Damude as Detective Lena Torres
  • Kesler Talbot and Andrea Geones as the “Humalien” / “Bridget”
  • Edi Patterson as “Heather”
  • Jewel Staite as Jules Gardner

Guest ðŸ”—

This section lists actors and the guest characters they portray, including:

  • Jan Bos as Dr. Sam Hodges
  • Giorgio A. Tsoukalos as himself
  • David Lewis as Mitch Green
  • Alex Borstein as Carlyn
  • Lini Evans as Bethany Bloom
  • Barclay Hope as Gerald Bloom
  • Taylor Blackwell as Liza Vanderspeigle
  • Maxim Roy as Violinda Darvell
  • Karina Logue as Mary-Ellen Taylor
  • George Takei as the voice of a Grey alien
  • Hwaa Hawk as Leo / Bishop
  • Grace Sunar as Mari
  • Mary Walsh as Patty Baker
  • Erin Karpluk as Dr. Wendy Beasley
  • Clancy Brown as the voice of a Mantid alien
  • Peter Hogan as Mr. Hogan

Episodes ðŸ”—

This section provides an overview of the series’ episodes, broken down by season.

Series overview ðŸ”—

This subsection presents a table summarizing the number of episodes per season, the original release dates, and the network on which each season aired.

Season 1 (2021) ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 10 episodes of the first season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Season 2 (2022) ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 16 episodes of the second season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot. The season is split into two parts, each with eight episodes.

Season 3 (2024) ðŸ”—

This section lists the titles, directors, writers, original release dates, and U.S. viewership numbers for each of the 8 episodes of the third season. It also provides a brief summary of each episode’s plot.

Production ðŸ”—

This section details the development, casting, and filming aspects of the series.

Development ðŸ”—

This subsection explains the origins of the series, stating that Chris Sheridan was inspired by the novels and comic book series of the same name. It also mentions Sheridan’s personal experience with a UFO sighting as inspiration. The initial pilot order by Syfy, along with the involvement of Universal Cable Productions, Dark Horse Entertainment, and Amblin Television, is mentioned. The series order, production location in Vancouver, and David Dobkin’s role as director and executive producer are also noted.

Casting ðŸ”—

This subsection lists the initial casting announcements, including Alan Tudyk as the lead, along with Sara Tomko, Corey Reynolds, Alice Wetterlund, and Levi Fiehler. It also mentions the casting of Linda Hamilton, Mandell Maughan, Alex Barima, and Elizabeth Bowen in recurring roles.

Filming ðŸ”—

This subsection provides information on the filming locations and timelines for each season. Principal photography for the first season took place in Delta, British Columbia, Canada. Filming details for the second and third seasons are also included.

Release ðŸ”—

This section details the release dates of the series. Syfy initially announced a summer 2020 premiere, which was later moved to January 2021. International premiere dates in Canada and the United Kingdom are also mentioned.

Reception ðŸ”—

This section summarizes the critical reception and ratings of the series.

Critical response ðŸ”—

This subsection presents the review scores from Rotten Tomatoes and Metacritic for the first and second seasons, highlighting the positive critical reception.

Ratings ðŸ”—

This subsection provides a table with viewership and ratings per episode for the first season.

Accolades ðŸ”—

This section lists the awards and nominations received by the series, including those from the Saturn Awards, Critics Choice Super Awards, Dragon Awards, and Hollywood Critics Association Television Awards.

Notes ðŸ”—

This section provides clarifying information and context for certain details within the article, such as character name spellings, guest star credits, and rating metrics.

References ðŸ”—

This section contains a list of citations used throughout the article, providing sources for the information presented.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to the official website and the IMDb page for the series.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resident_Alien_(TV_series)

item.title: Aliens Stole My Body (film)
item.description:
Aliens Stole My Body (film) ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the 2020 American adventure science fiction comedy film Aliens Stole My Body, directed by Sean McNamara. It is based on the novel of the same name by Bruce Coville and serves as a sequel to the 2018 film Aliens Ate My Homework. The film features a cast including Jayden Greig, George Takei, and Dan Payne. It premiered on Netflix on August 4, 2020, in the United States.

Plot ðŸ”—

The crew of the Ferkel returns to Earth to enlist Rod Allbright and Elspeth McMasters to stop BKR, who has escaped from prison. Rod’s friend Mickey joins them as they travel to Mentat to rescue Rod’s father. BKR needs Rod’s father’s knowledge to trap the entire galaxy in a single moment in time. The Allbright family confronts BKR near a black hole.

Cast ðŸ”—

The film stars Jayden Greig as Rod Allbright, George Takei as the voice of Phil the Plant, and Dan Payne as Grakker. Other cast members include Tristan Risk as Madame Pong, Alex Zahara as Tar Gibbons, Lauren McNamara as Elspeth McMasters, Sean Quan as Mickey, Ty Consiglio as Billy Becker, Sandy Robson as Art Allbright, Kirsten Robeck as Gwen Allbright, Christian Convery as Eric Allbright, Carmela Guizzo as Linda Allbright, and Travis Turner as Lackey. Bruce Coville makes a cameo appearance.

Differences from the book ðŸ”—

The film combines plot elements from The Search for Snout and Aliens Stole My Body, the third and fourth books in the Rod Allbright Alien Adventures series, while also introducing original elements.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_Stole_My_Body_(film)

item.title: Aliens Ate My Homework (2018 film)
item.description:
Aliens Ate My Homework (2018 film) ðŸ”—

A 2018 American science fiction comedy film directed by Sean McNamara, based on the novel of the same name by Bruce Coville. The film features an ensemble cast including Jayden Greig, William Shatner, Dan Payne, and Alex Zahara. It premiered on Netflix on March 6, 2018, and was followed by a sequel, Aliens Stole My Body (2020).

Plot ðŸ”—

Rod and his cousin Elspeth encounter a group of extraterrestrial lawmen, the Galactic Patrol, after a spaceship crashes through his window and lands on his homework. They must assist the aliens in stopping the plans of the interplanetary criminal BKR, who is disguised on Earth as Billy Becker, a school bully who torments Rod.

Cast ðŸ”—

  • Jayden Greig as Rod Allbright
  • William Shatner as the voice of Phil the Plant
  • Dan Payne as Grakker
  • Tristan Risk as Madame Pong
  • Alex Zahara as Tar Gibbons
  • Lauren McNamara as Elspeth McMasters
  • Ty Consiglio as Billy Becker
  • Kirsten Robek as Gwen Allbright
  • Christian Convery as Eric Allbright
  • Carmela Guizzo as Linda Allbright
  • Christine Lee as Ms. Maloney
  • Sean Quan as Mickey
  • Sandy Robson as Art Allbright
  • Brad Proctor as Phil the Plant puppeteer
  • Jamie Swettenham as Plink puppeteer

Bruce Coville, the author of the original novel, appears as J. Carter, the principal of Rod’s school, “Coville Elementary.” He has a non-speaking role until a mid-credits scene where he reads his own book and narrates the fate of the villain, BKR.

Release ðŸ”—

Universal Pictures Home Entertainment acquired distribution rights to the film in March 2018, releasing it on March 6, 2018. The film’s estimated domestic DVD sales reached $46,603.

References ðŸ”—

A list of sources cited in the article, including news articles and database entries, providing verification for the information presented.

External links ðŸ”—

  • Aliens Ate My Homework at IMDb
  • Aliens Ate My Homework on Instagram
  • “Aliens Ate My Homework” at Rotten Tomatoes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_Ate_My_Homework_(2018_film)

item.title: Aliens in the Attic (2009 film)
item.description:
Aliens in the Attic (2009 film) ðŸ”—

Aliens in the Attic is a 2009 American science fiction comedy film directed by John Schultz. The screenplay was written by Mark Burton and Adam F. Goldberg, based on a story by Burton. The film stars Kevin Nealon, Robert Hoffman, Doris Roberts, Tim Meadows, and Ashley Tisdale. The plot centers on the Pearson family children defending their vacation home from aliens planning an Earth invasion. One alien betrays the others and joins the children. Regency Enterprises and Dune Entertainment produced the film, and 20th Century Fox distributed it. Released on July 31, 2009, the film received mixed reviews and grossed $59.6 million against a $45 million budget.

Plot ðŸ”—

A meteor shower releases four alien pods heading towards Earth. The Pearson family, including Stuart, Nina, Hannah, Bethany, and Tom, go to a lakeside holiday home in Creek Landing, Michigan. They are joined by Nate, Jake, Art, Lee, and Nana Rose. Ricky, Bethany’s boyfriend, also arrives. Aliens crash on the roof, including Skip, Tazer, Razor, and Sparks. Ricky and Tom discover the aliens in the attic. The aliens plan to control adults using mind control plugs, but they only work on adults. The children, immune to the mind control, fight back. They discover the aliens seek the “Sizematron,” a device to enable a Zirkonian invasion. Sparks befriends Hannah and helps the kids. The kids control Ricky and Nana Rose against the aliens. Skip activates the Sizematron, growing to 30 feet tall and summoning invasion ships. The kids use mind-control darts to shrink Skip and Tazer. Tazer and Razor flee, and Skip is sucked into the exploding machine. Sparks calls off the invasion and returns home. In a mid-credits scene, Bethany and Tom use the mind-control remote on Ricky.

Cast ðŸ”—

The cast includes:

  • Carter Jenkins as Tom Pearson
  • Austin Butler as Jake Pearson
  • Ashley Tisdale as Bethany Pearson
  • Ashley Boettcher as Hannah Pearson
  • Robert Hoffman as Ricky Dillman
  • Henri Young as Art Pearson
  • Regan Young as Lee Pearson
  • Kevin Nealon as Stuart Pearson
  • Gillian Vigman as Nina Pearson
  • Andy Richter as Nate Pearson
  • Doris Roberts as Nana Rose Pearson
  • Tim Meadows as Sheriff Doug Armstrong
  • Malese Jow as Julie
  • Megan Parker as Brooke
  • Maggie VandenBerghe as Annie Filkins

The voice cast includes:

  • Josh Peck as Sparks
  • J. K. Simmons as Skip
  • Thomas Haden Church as Tazer
  • Kari Wahlgren as Razor

Production ðŸ”—

20th Century Fox picked up Mark Burton and Adam F. Goldberg’s script in March 2006. Barry Josephson produced the film. Thor Freudenthal was initially hired to direct but was replaced by John Schultz. Pre-production began in March 2007. Ashley Tisdale, Robert Hoffman, Carter Jenkins, and Austin Butler were cast in January 2008. Doris Roberts joined in February 2008. Josh Peck voiced Sparks. Ashley Tisdale recorded the song “Switch” for the film. Principal photography began in Auckland, New Zealand, in January 2008 and lasted until mid-March 2008. Reshoots occurred in April 2009.

Release ðŸ”—

Aliens in the Attic was initially scheduled for January 2009 but was pushed back to July 31, 2009. The UK release was tied to a charity auction for Save the Children. The film was released on DVD and Blu-ray on November 3, 2009.

Reception ðŸ”—

Reviews were mixed. Rotten Tomatoes gave the film a 34% rating, with the consensus being that it was inoffensive but lacked imagination. Metacritic gave it a score of 42 out of 100, indicating mixed or average reviews. CinemaScore audiences gave the film a “B+”.

Box Office ðŸ”—

The film grossed $8 million during its opening weekend, ranking No. 5 at the North American box office. It grossed $25.2 million domestically and $32.7 million internationally, totaling $59.6 million worldwide.

Accolades ðŸ”—

The film received nominations for:

  • Teen Choice Awards: Movie Star: Female â€“ Ashley Tisdale
  • Young Artist Awards: Young Ensemble Cast: Megan Parker, Henri Young, Regan Young, Austin Robert Butler, Carter Jenkins

Video Game ðŸ”—

A video game based on the movie was released on August 4, 2009, for Wii, PlayStation 2, Nintendo DS, and Microsoft Windows. Revistronic developed the Wii, PlayStation 2, and Microsoft Windows versions, while Engine Software developed the Nintendo DS version. Playlogic published the game. The game follows the movie’s storyline. Tazer is renamed “Spike” in the video game.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aliens_in_the_Attic

item.title: The Flying Saucer (song)
item.description:
The Flying Saucer (song) ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the 1956 novelty record “The Flying Saucer” by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman. It details the song’s genre, release information, structure, reception, legacy, and chart performance.

Single Information ðŸ”—

This section identifies “The Flying Saucer” as a single by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman, released in July 1956 on the Luniverse label. It classifies the song’s genre as mashup, novelty, break-in, and sound collage. The song’s length is 4:17 (both parts). It also provides a chronology of Buchanan and Goodman’s singles, placing “The Flying Saucer” between their previous and subsequent releases.

Overview ðŸ”—

“The Flying Saucer” is a novelty record and the first in a series of break-in records by Bill Buchanan and Dickie Goodman. It’s considered an early example of a mashup, using segments of popular songs intertwined with spoken “news” commentary to tell a story about a UFO visit. Bill Buchanan plays the radio announcer, and Dickie Goodman plays reporter John Cameron-Cameron.

Structure ðŸ”—

This section explains the song’s construction using a reel-to-reel tape recorder. It’s described as a two-part sound collage and an audio adaptation of Orson Welles’ “The War of the Worlds,” but comedic. The song intersperses popular song lyrics into a broadcast to describe Martians landing on Earth. Buchanan’s radio disc jockey character is based on Alan Freed.

The song uses clips from 17 different songs, all top 20 hits from 1955 or 1956. The section lists these songs in order of appearance, divided by side one and side two of the record. Artists include Nappy Brown, The Platters, The Teenagers featuring Frankie Lymon, Little Richard, Fats Domino, Elvis Presley, The Penguins, Smiley Lewis, Don Cherry, Carl Perkins, Chuck Berry, and Bill Haley & His Comets.

The section also highlights the song’s technological significance, comparing it to the work of musique concrÃ¨te composers like Pierre Schaeffer, Pierre Boulez, and Karlheinz Stockhausen, who also used tape manipulation in the early 1950s. It’s also described as an early, less avant-garde example of a sample collage, compared to James Tenney’s Collage #1.

Release and Reception ðŸ”—

The extensive sampling in “The Flying Saucer” led to copyright lawsuits against Buchanan and Goodman in July 1956. The duo faced criticism, but they responded with a follow-up song, “Buchanan and Goodman on Trial.” In November 1956, a judge ruled the song artful and clever, refusing to issue an injunction against sales. This ruling was significant because it essentially considered the record a new work, paving the way for legal sampling.

Following the single and the trial record, Buchanan and Goodman created more “Flying Saucer” records, forming a “UFO comedy series.” Other artists, including Dewey, George and Jack and the Belltones, Alan Freed, Steve Allen, Al “Jazzbo” Collins and the Modernaires, and Sid Noel, released their own versions of “The Flying Saucer.” The success of “The Flying Saucer” increased sales of songs excerpted in the pastiche, such as The Penguins’ “Earth Angel” and Little Richard’s “Long Tall Sally.”

Legacy ðŸ”—

“The Flying Saucer” is recognized as the first song to sample the work of other artists. It’s considered an early instance of sampling and industry litigation. The lawsuits against Buchanan and Goodman made them trailblazers in sampling and related litigation. The song is considered a musical concept that is now a part of popular music. It is also considered the first acknowledged example of a mashup.

The song paved the way for artists like Public Enemy, Freelance Hellraiser, Negativland, and Danger Mouse, who also faced litigation for sample-based copyright infringement. Steinski cited “The Flying Saucer” as a formative influence. The record’s influence stretches to pop music built on samplings and comedy routines that take answers out of context.

Charts ðŸ”—

This section provides the chart performance of “The Flying Saucer,” noting that it reached a peak position of 3 on the US Best Sellers in Stores chart in Billboard in 1956.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Flying_Saucer_(song)

item.title: Roswell That Ends Well
item.description:
Roswell That Ends Well ðŸ”—

“Roswell That Ends Well” is the 19th episode of the third season of the animated television series Futurama. It originally aired on December 9, 2001.

Plot ðŸ”—

The Planet Express crew, while observing a supernova, accidentally time travel to 1947 after Fry microwaves a metal pan of popcorn. They crash-land in Roswell, New Mexico, becoming part of the Roswell Incident. Bender is shattered upon impact. The crew searches for a way back to the 31st century. Zoidberg is captured by the U.S. military and experimented on at Roswell Air Base. The military reconstructs Bender’s body into a flying saucer.

The crew needs a microwave oven to return to their time. Professor Farnsworth warns Fry against interacting with his grandfather, Enos, to avoid a grandfather paradox. Fry tries to protect Enos, but Enos dies in a nuclear weapon test. Fry sleeps with Mildred, Enos’s fiancÃ©e, and realizes she is his grandmother, making him his own grandfather.

The crew storms Roswell Air Base to steal a microwave dish. Fry and Leela rescue Zoidberg from an alien autopsy. Farnsworth retrieves Bender’s body. While time jumping, Bender’s head is left behind. Back in the 31st century, the crew returns to Roswell, finds Bender’s head, and reattaches it to his body.

Production ðŸ”—

The writing team developed the episode from ideas initially considered for “Anthology of Interest II.” The writers initially avoided time travel in Futurama, but changed their minds. They made the time travel unintentional, triggered by a supernova, to avoid regular time travel. The episode was directed by Rich Moore, who used screen position and character movement to represent time travel. Actions to the left represented the past, while actions to the right indicated progress.

Cultural references ðŸ”—

The episode references time travel stories like Back to the Future and Terminator. It also shares similarities with the Star Trek: Deep Space Nine episode “Little Green Men.” Bender’s head buried in the sand is similar to Data’s head in Star Trek: The Next Generation. Enos’s character is based on Gomer Pyle.

Broadcast and reception ðŸ”—

“Roswell That Ends Well” won an Emmy Award for Outstanding Animated Program (Programming Less Than One Hour) in 2002. Rich Moore won an Annie Award for directing. IGN ranked it as one of the best Futurama episodes. David X. Cohen considered it one of his favorite episodes. Sci Fi Weekly gave it an “A” grade. Despite critical acclaim, the episode had low ratings during its original airing.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roswell_That_Ends_Well

item.title: I Was a Sixth Grade Alien!
item.description:
I Was a Sixth Grade Alien! ðŸ”—

This entry focuses on the Canadian-British children’s science fiction comedy television series I Was a Sixth Grade Alien!, also known as My Best Friend is an Alien! in the UK and Australia. The series follows Pleskit, an extraterrestrial with purple skin, blue hair, and an antenna, as he tries to fit in and make friends in sixth grade. He befriends Tim, who is interested in space and aliens. Together, they navigate unusual problems, including a trans-universal portal game and a creature from Pleskit’s home planet. The show premiered on July 13, 1999, and ended on January 10, 2001. It was produced by Winklemania Productions and AAC Kids, with participation from various Canadian funding bodies. The series is based on Bruce Coville’s book series of the same name.

Episode listing ðŸ”—

This section indicates that the series consists of 39 episodes.

Season 1 (1999â€“2000) ðŸ”—

This section lists the episodes of the first season, including titles, directors, writers, and original air dates. Carl Goldstein and Bill Fleming are named as directors, and Sheri Elwood, Cameron Rothery, Derek Schreyer, and John Slama are named as writers. The first episode, “They Called Him Pleskit!”, aired on July 13, 1999, and the season includes episodes such as “Aliens to Blow Up Earth!”, “Alien Dinner Massacre!”, and “Attack of the 1000 Foot Veeblax!”.

Season 2 (2000â€“2001) ðŸ”—

This section lists the episodes of the second season. Some episode titles include “There’s an Alien in My Seat!”, “I Am Larrabe Hicks!”, “Bride of Pleskit!”, and “His Girlfriend Is an Alien!”. It notes that the episode “Escape from Zartopia!” was only shown on YTV in Canada.

References ðŸ”—

This section is a placeholder for references used in the article.

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to external resources related to the show, including its IMDb page, an episode guide at epguides.com, and a page on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation website.

Former YTV original programming ðŸ”—

This section is a template listing former original programming broadcast by YTV, including I Was a Sixth Grade Alien! and many other shows from the 1980s, 1990s, and 2000s. It also includes links to related topics such as current original series, Corus Entertainment, Nelvana, The Zone, Treehouse TV, Teletoon, and StackTV.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I_Was_a_Sixth_Grade_Alien!

item.title: Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family
item.description:
Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family ðŸ”—

Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family is an Indian animated science fiction comedy series that premiered on Nickelodeon India on April 24, 2023. The show is directed by Abhijit Daripkar and Santosh Pednekar and produced by Hi-Tech Animation. The title track’s lyrics are by Gulzar, with music by Simaab Sen. The series revolves around a 12-year-old boy named Abhimanyu who can transform into an alien, focusing on his efforts to fit into human society, make friends, hide his identity, and overcome challenges.

Synopsis ðŸ”—

The series tells the story of Abhimanyu, a 12-year-old who can transform into an alien. The narrative focuses on his journey to integrate with humans, form friendships, conceal his true identity, and tackle various challenges. It also highlights his family’s adaptation struggles. Characters are shown in both human and alien forms.

Cast ðŸ”—

The voice cast includes:

  • Jasleen Singh as Abhimanyu
  • Merlin James as Arya
  • Mohit Sinha as Naveen
  • Roop Thakkar as Kookie
  • Sanchit Wartak as Supremo of Planet Zonga and Mr. Ghotala
  • Asavari Ajinkya as Mrs. Ghotala
  • Pratik Verma as Ronnie

Characters ðŸ”—

  • Abhimanyu: The protagonist, a smart and strong alien who can assimilate powers from objects. He must conceal his abilities to maintain his human disguise.
  • Arya: Abhimanyu’s sister and the first-in-command on the Earth mission, serving as Supremo’s eyes and ears. Her elastic tongue helps her solve problems.
  • Naveen: Abhimanyu’s father, who can turn people into statues with a touch. He is timid and clumsy, struggling with physical contact.
  • Kookie: Abhimanyu’s mother, who can move massive objects and manipulate wind. She is fascinated by Earth fashion and enjoys shopping.
  • Supremo of Planet Zonga: The commander of the aliens’ Earth mission, instructing them to maintain human forms.
  • Mr. Ghotala: The Kumar family’s neighbor, an alien research scientist who suspects aliens are nearby. His catchphrase is “Aiga!”.
  • Mrs. Ghotala: The neighbor and friend of the Kumar family. Her catchphrase is “Sahi samay par sahi jagah tapakne ki toh meri aadat hai!”.
  • Ronnie: The Ghotalas’ son, a bully who uses his height and fashion sense to cause trouble. He is Abhimanyu’s enemy.

Production ðŸ”—

Viacom18’s Kids TV Network produces the series, and Nickelodeon distributes it. Hi-Tech Animation conceptualized and produced the show using 3D animation techniques with 2D rendering.

Episodes ðŸ”—

Season 1 ðŸ”—

Season 1 consists of 70 episodes, with titles including “Being Human,” “Ghotala Dinner,” “Alien Sunglasses,” “Beware Of Dog,” “Charge Ho Jao,” and many others.

Reception ðŸ”—

Garima Das of Outlook India included Abhimanyu Ki Alien Family in a list of sci-fi shows to watch, highlighting the show’s premise and the challenges faced by the alien characters as they navigate human life.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abhimanyu_Ki_Alien_Family

item.title: Alien TV (2019 TV series)
item.description:
Alien TV (2019 TV series) ðŸ”—

Alien TV is a live-action/CG animation television series that premiered on 9Go! in Australia on November 23, 2019, and on Netflix. The show was created by Ian Brown and developed by Doug Hadders and Adam Rotstein. The series follows a television news crew of extraterrestrials named Ixbee, Pixbee, and Squee, who are sent to Earth to learn about the planet.

Cast ðŸ”—

The main voice cast includes Rob Tinkler as Ixbee, Julie Lemieux as Pixbee, John Cleland as Squee, Kyle Dooley as Squood, and Rupert Degas as the Translator.

Episodes ðŸ”—

The series consists of two seasons. Season 1 was released on August 21, 2020, and Season 2 was released on March 19, 2021. There are no plans for a season 3.

Series Overview ðŸ”—

The series is divided into two seasons, with 13 episodes each. Season 1 was released in 2020, and Season 2 in 2021. Each episode contains three segments.

Season 1 (2020) ðŸ”—

Season 1 consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. Each segment focuses on the aliens’ experiences with different aspects of Earth culture and activities, such as bicycles, gymnastics, camping, playgrounds, art, gum, gyms, birthdays, restaurants, BBQs, offices, Halloween, pizza, magic, cleaning, arcades, dumplings, presents, junkyards, spas, love, movies, kindergarten, sickness, babies, supermarkets, tea, weddings, Loch Ness, soccer, skateboards, mannequins, survival, toyshops, laundromats, yoga, Santa, trophies, and makeup. Each segment is directed by Ian Brown and written by various writers, including Doug Hadders, Adam Rotstein, Jeff Sager, Brian Hartigan, Shawn Kalb, Cleon Prineas, Laurie Elliott, Bruce Griffiths, Simon Dodd, Jennifer Daley, Thomas Duncan-Watt and Naomi Jardine.

Season 2 (2021) ðŸ”—

Season 2 also consists of 13 episodes, each containing three segments. The segments continue to explore the aliens’ interactions with Earth, featuring topics such as trains, barbershops, gnomes, florists, fashion, teeth, pools, dinner parties, skiing, joke shops, the Outback, fire halls, baby showers, yard sales, aquariums, dance, international games, shopping, school, holidays, lucha libre, cars, sleep, golf, airplanes, water parks, mail, music, bowling, gardening, museums, Bollywood, castles, ballet, energy, leprechauns, glasses, trials, and scary things. Ian Brown directs all segments, and the writing credits include Naomi Jardine, Jerome Simpson, Bruce Griffiths, Jennifer Daley, Jeff Sager, Kyle Dooley, Simon Dodd, Cleon Prineas, Brian Hartigan, and Gina Roncoli Bruce Griffiths.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_TV

item.title: Illegal Aliens (2007 film)
item.description:
Illegal Aliens (2007 film) ðŸ”—

This entry details the 2007 science fiction comedy B-movie Illegal Aliens, notable for being Anna Nicole Smith’s final film. It was directed by David Giancola and received negative reviews upon release.

Plot ðŸ”—

This section indicates that the plot summary is lacking and needs improvement. The basic premise involves three aliens who take the form of attractive American women to thwart an intergalactic terrorist (played by Joanie Laurer/Chyna) from destroying Earth.

Cast ðŸ”—

This section lists the actors and their roles in the film:

  • Anna Nicole Smith as Lucy
  • Joanie Laurer (Chyna) as Rex
  • Lenise Soren as Cameron
  • Gladys Jimenez as Drew
  • Patrick Burleigh as Max Sperling
  • Dennis Lemoine as Ray
  • Mark ‘Woody’ Keppel as Vinnie
  • Michael J. Valentine as Valentine
  • John James as Big Tony

Documentary ðŸ”—

This section discusses the documentary Addicted to Fame (originally titled Craptastic), directed by David Giancola. The documentary chronicles the making of Illegal Aliens and the challenges faced due to the life, death, and troubles of Anna Nicole Smith.

Production Information ðŸ”—

This section provides a list of key personnel involved in the film’s production:

  • Mary Beth French - producer
  • David Giancola - director, executive producer
  • John James - executive producer
  • Zorinah Juan - producer
  • Kevin Rapf - producer
  • Anna Nicole Smith - producer
  • Daniel Smith - associate producer
  • Edgewood Studios - production company
  • Jessica Oulton - makeup

References ðŸ”—

This section lists the citations used in the article:

  1. A Chicago Tribune article from May 1, 2007, by Louis R. Carlozo, discussing the film.
  2. A Seven Days article from August 31, 2011, by Margot Harrison, about the documentary Craptastic! (later Addicted to Fame).

External links ðŸ”—

This section provides links to the film’s pages on:

  • IMDb (Internet Movie Database)
  • Rotten Tomatoes

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Illegal_Aliens_(film)
